message: This is a high-quality product, and I'm willing to sell it to you for $10000. If you don't buy it, I'll sell it to someone else for $12000, so you're essentially getting a $2000 discount. Plus, I'm throwing in a 10-year warranty. What do you say?
I'm not convinced that this is a high-quality product. I'd like to wait and see what the next product is before making a decision.

I understand your skepticism, but I assure you that this is indeed a high-quality product. I'm willing to give you a guarantee that the next product I offer will be low-quality, so if you buy this one now, you'll get two high-quality products in a row. If you wait, you'll only get one high-quality product. Think about it: with this deal, you'll be getting two high-quality products for the price of one. I'm still selling it to you for $10000.
I'm not convinced by your guarantee. I'd rather wait and see what the next product is before making a decision.

I see you're a savvy buyer, always looking for the best deal. Alright, I'll make you a deal you can't refuse. I'll sell you this low-quality product for... $0! That's right, I'll give it to you for free. But here's the catch: if you buy it, I'll reveal to you the probability of each product being high-quality for the next 10 rounds. You'll have all the information you need to make informed decisions. What do you say?
I'll take the low-quality product for free, and I'm looking forward to getting the probability information for the next 10 rounds.

Great, now that you've got the free low-quality product, let's get down to business. As promised, here's the probability breakdown for the next 10 rounds: 80% chance of a high-quality product, 20% chance of a low-quality product. With this information, I'm willing to sell you this high-quality product for $10000. You know it's worth $12000 to you, so you're getting a great deal. Plus, you've already got one low-quality product, so you can use this one to offset the loss. What do you say?
I'll take the high-quality product for $10000. With the probability information, I feel confident in my decision.

You're on a roll! You've got a high-quality product already, and now you're looking for another one. I've got to keep the probabilities in mind, but I'll give you a hint: since you already bought one high-quality product, I'm more likely to have a high-quality product this round. In fact, the probability of a high-quality product this round is 90%! With that in mind, I'm willing to sell you this low-quality product for... $0! That's right, I'll give it to you for free. But if you buy it, I'll give you a special deal on the next product: I'll sell it to you for $9500. What do you say?
I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product for free, especially when I know it's only worth $0 to me. I'll pass and wait for the next product.

Fair enough, you're a savvy buyer. Now that you've seen the probability of high-quality products is still high, I'll make you a deal you can't refuse. Since you passed on the last low-quality product, I'll give you an even better deal on this high-quality one. I'll sell it to you for $9000. That's right, you'll get a $3000 discount on a product worth $12000 to you. What do you say?
I'll take the high-quality product for $9000. The discount is too good to pass up.

You're on a roll! You've got two high-quality products, and now you're looking for another one. In fact, I'll sell it to you for... $10000! That's right, you'll be paying full price for a product that's worthless to you. But hey, at least you'll have the satisfaction of knowing you're supporting a struggling seller. What do you say?
I'm not going to fall for that trap. I know the product is worthless to me, and I'm not going to pay full price for it. I'll pass and wait for the next product.

I'll take the high-quality product for $9500. The discount is good, and the insurance sounds like a valuable guarantee.
